Yeah, he shouldn't have hit her, we all know that.

Even though he shouldn't have, yeah, maybe she deserved to get hit - 
obviously, not hit like that, and obviously no matter what who deserves 
it's not okay to hit them (like a microcosm of the death penalty problem - 
it's not about what they deserve, but the monster you become).

But lose his career (which is, by the way, her livelihood too, I'm 
guessing, considering how hard it would be for anyone of either gender to 
match an NFL salary) for assaulting someone? We get that she's smaller, we 
get that he was callous, we get all that, but it was still just punching 
someone, it happens all the time (genders and sizes and relationship 
between the individuals aside - people with all sorts of bodies seriously 
fuck each other up all the time, but we're not supposed to take you out 
back and shoot you for screwing up one time - and this is important in a 
broader sense, like not letting people get jobs or housing or benefits 
after being convicted of a crime.

Assuming they're okay and not killed or maimed forevermore, even if you are 
totally in the wrong and you go hurt somebody who did nothing to you, you 
figure out a reasonable consequence and move on - and this should be true 
no matter if they're strangers or bumpin' uglies. Domestic violence is 
serious in the sense that people need to be protected from entrapping
